ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: First and foremost, I learned a lot of important facts from this course. I also learned how to apply these facts to more modern times, read sources critically, and craft historical arguments.

I had never heard before that Greece is/was part of the Near East. Now I understand the incredibly significant ways in which "Western" and "Near Eastern" cultures influenced one another. I also understand the modern world in a new light because of the fault lines - geographical, cultural, etc. - that Professor Foster illustrated.
This was my first history course so it was a good way to know how to study for such a course.
A thorough understanding of the history of the near east from the time of Alexander to Muhammad.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is a wonderful course! The highlight is Professor Foster--his lectures are always riveting and informative. The chronology in the second half of the course is occasionally difficult to follow, but it is still very interesting.
This is an incredibly comprehensive course of the world of Late Antiquity. There are few ways to improve it - every lecture and reading brought new insights into this world.
It had a lot of readings and the key terms were very many even though we were tested on approximately 10.
The course is logically structured and easy to follow. I wouldn't change any part of it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would certainly recommend this course. The topic is very under-appreciated these days, and Professor Foster makes it come to life.
It's so worth it. You'll never look at the modern world the same way.
Yes because the topic is interesting and the lecturing, Ben Foster, makes a compelling argument as to how the middle east developed.

I would recommend this course to a student so long as they had a decent interest in history. If they don't find the subject matter interesting, they won't enjoy the course, but in my opinion the subject is engaging.
